sources.data_found: NSF Award #2215967 (Start Date: Oct 1, 2022): 'Acquisition of a Heterogeneous High-Performance Computing System...'. The system consists of 'two head nodes, eight compute nodes, and two GPU nodes.' The GPU nodes are equipped with NVIDIA A100 GPUs.

student_data.notes: Data from Louisiana Tech Fact Book 2023-2024 (Fall 2023 Census). 'Undergrad' is BS Computer Science (442). 'Grad' is MS Computer Science (43). 'PhD' count uses the 'Computational Analysis & Modeling' (CAM) program (27) as it is the primary interdisciplinary doctoral program for CS research at LaTech; there is also a 'PhD in Engineering' (114 total) which includes Cyberspace Engineering students, but the specific CS/Cyber breakdown is not listed, so the CAM number is used as a verified minimum. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

gpu_resources.notes: GPU Count Estimation: The NSF Award #2215967 (active 2022-2025) funded a cluster with 'two GPU nodes' equipped with 'NVIDIA A100 GPUs'. The budget ($450k) and standard HPC configurations for that period typically include 4x GPUs per node. Therefore, the total is estimated at 2 nodes × 4 GPUs = 8 A100s. VRAM is assumed 80GB given the 'AI and Data Science' research focus of the grant. NOTE: Louisiana Tech is also a member of LONI (Louisiana Optical Network Infrastructure) giving access to the 'QB3' cluster (44x V100s shared across LA universities), but these are not listed here as they are not university-owned local resources.

analysis_notes: Primary local GPU resource is the NSF-funded heterogeneous cluster (Awarded late 2022). Student counts are precise from the official University Fact Book. Access to LONI shared supercomputers (QB3) significantly augments capacity but is excluded from local inventory counts.
